title: reference request - Primes dividing functions defined by linear recurrence relations with constant coefficients
body: For Fibonacci numbers $F_n$ it holds that $p|F_{p-(\frac{5}{p})}$ , if $p$ is an odd prime (Legendre symbol). I guessed that the number $5$ came from the roots of the characteristic polynomial and tried the following approach: Given $a,b\in\mathbb Z^+$ (for simplicity), and let $F_{a,b}:\mathbb N\to\mathbb N$ be a function such that $F_{a,b}(0)=0$ , $F_{a,b}(1)=1$ and $F_{a,b}(n+1)=a\cdot F_{a,b}(n)+b\cdot F_{a,b}(n-1)$ . Conjecture: If $a,b$ are co-prime and $p>2$ is a prime that doesn't divide $b$ , then $F_{a,b}\left(p-\left(\frac{a^2+4b}{p}\right)\right)\equiv 0\pmod p$ , Is this conjecture correct and known? I have tested the conjecture with $50000$ randomly selected $a,b,p$ . That is, three numbers $1\le a',b'\le 100$ and $3\le p'\le 10000$ are selected with uniform distribution, then $a=\frac{a'}{gcd(a',b')},b=\frac{b'}{gcd(a',b')}$ and $p$ is set to the least prime $\ge p'$ . reference-request prime-numbers recurrences conjectures Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jun 15, 2020 at 7:27 Community Bot 1 2 2 silver badges 3 3 bronze badges asked Feb 17, 2017 at 10:56 Lehs 862 9 9 silver badges 18 18 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 4 3 $\begingroup$ Your sequence is a Lucas sequence of the first kind. Your conjecture is true and well known. It is listed under "Other Relations" here: en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucas_sequence . $\endgroup$ Ofir Gorodetsky –  Ofir Gorodetsky 2017-02-17 13:03:03 +00:00 Commented Feb 17, 2017 at 13:03 $\begingroup$ @OfirGorodetsky. Yes, I found it. But the condition of the conjecture is not as hard $p\nmid b$ and on Wikipedia $p\nmid ab(a^2+4b)$. So far I have not found a counter-example of the condition in the conjecture. $\endgroup$ Lehs –  Lehs 2017-02-17 15:08:58 +00:00 Commented Feb 17, 2017 at 15:08 $\begingroup$ The other conditions in the Wikipedia page are redundant, the proof does not require them. Your conditions suffice. I suspect that even requiring $a,b$ to be coprime is redundant. $\endgroup$ Ofir Gorodetsky –  Ofir Gorodetsky 2017-02-17 23:42:28 +00:00 Commented Feb 17, 2017 at 23:42 $\begingroup$ @OfirGorodetsky, you seems to be right. The co-prime condition was a faulty intuition: I immediately saw that there was something in the $a^2+4b$ but that some conditions was necessary. I have tested without the co-prime condition and with negative $b$ ($a^2>4b$) and the only necessary condition seems to be that $p$ shouldn't divide $b$. $\endgroup$ Lehs –  Lehs 2017-02-18 07:20:50 +00:00 Commented Feb 18, 2017 at 7:20 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
